caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC v THE HIGH COURT (COMMERCIAL DIVISION) ACCRA E
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana ruling addresses whether the High Court (Commercial Division) had jurisdiction to hear a fresh action challenging an aspect of a consent judgment concerning the interest rate on a loan. The Trust Bank Ltd. had obtained a consent judgment against Ampomah Photo Lab Ltd. and others, but later unilaterally included an interest rate of 35% per annum in the entry of judgment, which was not specified in the original agreement. The defendants filed a new action to set aside this interest provision, claiming mistake and misrepresentation. The Supreme Court held that a fresh action to challenge a consent judgment is a valid legal remedy, especially where appeal is not available. It emphasized that its supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 of the Constitution applies only to fundamental or jurisdictional errors, not mere errors of law. Citing English and Ghanaian precedents, the Court affirmed that consent judgments, being based on agreement, can be set aside on grounds such as mistake, just like any contract. Therefore, the High Court was within its jurisdiction to entertain the fresh action, and the Supreme Court declined to issue certiorari.
legalKeywords: fresh action to set aside judgment
verdict: The Supreme Court dismissed the application for certiorari, holding that the High Court had jurisdiction to hear the fresh action challenging the consent judgment on grounds of mistake.
winningSide: The High Court (Commercial Division) Accra and the Interested Parties
citations: Republic v High Court Accra, Ex Parte CHRAJ [2003-2004] SCGLR 1
Republic v Court of Appeal, Ex Parte Tsatsu Tsikata [2005-2006] SCGLR 612
Huddersfield Banking Company Ltd. v Henry Lister & Son Ltd. [1895] 2 Ch. D 273
rationaleHighlights: A High Court may entertain a fresh action to challenge a consent judgment based on mistake, as appeals are generally not available against such judgments.
The Supreme Court will only exercise supervisory jurisdiction where there is a patent, fundamental error of law or a jurisdictional defect.
A consent judgment, while binding, is rooted in agreement and can be set aside on grounds that would invalidate a contract, including mistake.
The High Court is not functus officio regarding matters not finally determined in the original judgment.
The entry of interest terms not agreed upon may constitute a misrepresentation of the consent agreement.
confidenceNotes: The case is unreported but contains detailed judicial reasoning and citation of both local and foreign authorities. The analysis is thorough and consistent with established principles of civil procedure and jurisdiction in Ghana.
